profileText: A Senator from California; born in Santa Barbara, Calif., November 23, 1876; attended the public schools; graduated from Stanford University, Palo Alto, Calif., 1898; editor and publisher of Santa Barbara News-Press and its predecessors; rancher and citrus fruit grower; postmaster, Santa Barbara 1914-1921; appointed on November 9, 1938, as a Democrat to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of William Gibbs McAdoo and served from November 9, 1938, to January 3, 1939; was not a candidate for election for the full term; resumed newspaper business; member, California Crime Commission 1951-1952; member of the board of regents of University of California 1955-1960; died in Santa Barbara, Calif., October 12, 1971; interment in Santa Barbara Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Storke, Thomas More. I Write for Freedom. Fresno: McNally & Loftin, 1963.
Storke, Thomas More, with Walter A. Tompkins. California Editor. Los Angeles: Westernlore Press, 1958.

researchRecord.name: Discussed in interview (1989) with Don W. MacGillicray, 271 pages.

Ca. 1906-1971. 35 linear feet. Correspondence, biographical material including memoirs, speeches, financial records, subject files, clippings, scrapbooks, photographs, and genealogical materials. Topics include his newspaper career, opposition to John Birch Society, civic interests, operation of his ranches, and service as regent of University of California, 1955-1960. Finding aid. Additional letters in several collections.
